title: The Fed Is ABOUT TO PRINT!! Watch This NOW!!
transcript: My colleagues and I remain squarely focused [music] on achieving our dual mandate goals of maximum employment and stable prices for the benefit of the American people. The Federal Reserve says they're fighting inflation. They say they are committed to a 2% target and that they're well positioned to wait and see. But the charts tell a very different story. While everyone is distracted [music] by the quarter point rate cut and the drama of the dissenting votes, we're staring down the barrel of a massive liquidity injection in 2026 that could send crypto and other assets parabolic. [music] It's a phenomenon that some macro analysts are calling the everything code. And if you understand how it works, you realize that the Fed doesn't actually have a choice. [music] They have to print. So, in this video, we're going to explain exactly what happened at the FOMC yesterday, the massive wall of debt that is about to hit the US Treasury, and why 2026 could be the year of the liquidity flood. My name is Guy, and you're watching the Coin Bureau. First up though, I must make one thing clear. I am not a financial adviser. I'm just a chap on the internet reading the tea leaves of the financial elite so you don't have to. This is educational content meant to show you why the money printer might be dusting itself off for a comeback tour. If that sounds interesting or indeed terrifying, hit that like button and let's get into it. So, what actually happened at yesterday's FOMC meeting? Well, on the 10th of December, the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by 25 basis points, bringing the Federal Funds rate to a range of 3.5% to 3.75%. Now, on the surface, that sounds like business as usual. It's the third rate cut this year. But if you pull back the curtain a little bit, this meeting was anything but normal. We saw a historic division within the committee as three members voted against the cut. And that's the most dissenting voices we've seen since September 2019. And it wasn't just them. Four [snorts] other non-voting participants registered soft dissents. Basically, [snorts] half the room didn't want to do this. Why? Because inflation is sticky. Core PCE is hovering around 2.8% well above their target. So, Fed Chair Jerome Pal came out and gave what the market is calling a hawkish cut. He warned that future cuts will be tougher to justify and that they are quote well positioned to wait. Now, Powell is talking tough because he wants history to remember him as the guy who beat inflation before his tenure as chair ends next year. But here's the kicker. The market doesn't believe him. Traders are pricing in a 68% chance of two or more cuts next year. Why? Well, because of who is likely coming next. Jerome Pal's term ends in May 2026. And right now, the front runner to replace him is Kevin Hasset. According to Prediction Markets, Hasset has a 72% chance of taking the hot seat, and he's what you might call an inflation dove. He's publicly stated that if he were at the helm, he would be cutting rates aggressively right now. He's even argued for rates well below 3%. Now, this creates a shadow chair scenario. Even if Powell wants to hold the line, the market is looking past him to a successor who seems perfectly willing to turn the liquidity taps back on to please the administration. But >> it's not about politics. >> There's a much bigger, much scarier reason why the Fed might be forced to pivot regardless of who sits in the chair. Yes, we need to talk about the debt refinancing wall. So, the US government has a problem, a $9.2 trillion problem. That's the amount of US Treasury debt maturing in 2025 and is roughly onethird of all outstanding marketable debt. And in 2026, up to another $9 trillion comes due. Here's the maths that keeps Treasury Secretary Scott Bessant awake at night. You see, a lot of this debt was issued years ago when interest rates were near zero. Now, it has to be refinanced and at rates that are double or triple what they were before. And this is already hurting. In 2025, the US spent $970 billion on interest payments alone. For 2026, that's projected to top $1 trillion. To put that into perspective, the US is spending more on servicing the debt than it spends on the entire defense budget. This is the fiscal dominance trap. If rates stay high, the interest payments explode, the deficit widens, and the government has to borrow even more just to pay the interest. It's a death spiral. And the only way out, lower rates. Whether inflation is beaten or not, the Treasury cannot afford to refinance around $18 trillion of debt at 5%. Something has to break. And this brings us to the everything code. Now, this chart is arguably the most important chart in crypto, and you'll likely have seen enough of it to last you a lifetime by now. It shows the correlation between global M2 money supply, that is the amount of cash sloshing around the world economy, and the price of Bitcoin. Historically, Bitcoin moves with global liquidity. In fact, it has a 0.94 correlation with global liquidity over the long term. It is the most sensitive asset to monetary expansion. When the money supply goes up, Bitcoin goes up. When the money supply contracts, Bitcoin struggles. And right now, the liquidity cycle is turning. China is already aggressively easing. They've injected roughly $1.5 trillion equivalent over the last 6 months to prop up their economy. Global M2 is currently sitting at around $96 trillion. And despite the Fed's tough talk, US M2 is growing at 4.6%. 6% year-over-year. The everything code suggests that we are entering a period of synchronized global easing. Central banks around the world are cutting rates. The US Treasury is quietly injecting liquidity through buybacks. And Bitcoin, Bitcoin is just waiting for the flood. Now, before we get into the terrifying prospect of yield curve control and what this means for your portfolio, I want to share something that could help you maximize your returns when this liquidity finally hits. If you're looking to position yourself for this potential liquidity cycle, you're going to need a reliable exchange, and you might as well get some bonuses while you're at it. This is where the Coin Bureau deals page comes in because this is where you'll find signup bonuses of up to $100,000, trading fee discounts of up to 50% and deposit cash backs of up to 75% on the best crypto exchanges in the industry. To get these offers, all you need to do is hit the link in the description or scan this QR code. Once you get on the deals page, find a deal that suits you and click one of the sign up now buttons. These deals won't be around forever though, so take advantage of them while you can using the link in the description below or the QR code on your screen. Okay, now back to the nightmare scenario for the dollar. We talked about the debt wall, but what happens if the market refuses to buy US debt at lower rates? What if bond vigilantes demand higher yields because they see the inflation risk? Well, enter yield curve control or YCC. This is the nuclear option. This is where the Fed effectively says, "We will buy unlimited amounts of government debt to keep interest rates low." We saw this in Japan. They pegged their 10-year yield near zero for years. It kept borrowing costs low, but it absolutely crushed the yen. And historically, the US has done this, too. back in the 1940s to fund World War II. If the Fed is forced to cap yields to prevent the US government from defaulting on its interest payments, that is effectively restarting quantitative easing or QE. That is money printing on steroids. Now, they might not call it QE, they might call it market functioning purchases or balance sheet stabilization, but make no mistake, it is liquidity. And there's one final piece of the puzzle, the electionyear effect. We know that governments love to spend money, but they really love to spend money around elections. Historical data shows that primary deficits rise significantly during election years. We're coming off the back of the great election year of 2024 and heading into the midterms in 2026. The fiscal tap is open. The deficit is running at nearly $2 trillion a year, and that money has to come from somewhere. So, let's put it all together. We have a Federal Reserve that's trying to talk tough, but is internally divided and about to be led by a dove. We have a debt refinancing wall of up to $18 trillion hitting in the next 24 months. We have global M2 money supply already expanding, led by China. and we have a fiscal situation that effectively demands lower interest rates to avoid a sovereign debt crisis. So, what's the verdict? Well, the macro setup for 2026 is looking like a perfect storm for liquidity assets. The Fed says they're fighting inflation, but the everything code, the reality of the debt and the money supply, suggests that they will be forced to print. Remember though, there is a lag. Bitcoin typically reacts to liquidity changes with a delay of about two to three months. With global liquidity picking up now and the debt wall looming in 2026, we could be staring at the start of a massive run. But here's the reality check. This doesn't mean number go up in a straight line. If inflation spikes again because of this liquidity, we could see volatility like never before. The Fed might try to slam on the brakes one last time before the dam breaks. However, if you believe that the government will choose inflation over default, and history suggests they always do, then the long-term trajectory for scarce assets like Bitcoin is pretty clear. The liquidity is coming. You just need to be patient. But what do you think? Is the Fed about to lose control of the bond market, or will Powell somehow manage a soft landing while refinancing $18 trillion in debt? Let me know your thoughts in the comments below. And if you want to understand more about how the global liquidity cycle actually works, then check out the video right over here. That's it for now, though. As always, thank you so much for watching, and I'll see you next time. This is Guy signing off.

title: Ben Cowen: 2025 Review & Whatâ€™s Coming for Crypto in 2026
transcript: I think it has been a disappointing year for altcoins for sure. You know, to speak bluntly, I mean, I I I think we've kind of lost our way this cycle in a sense. Like I think a lot of people were focused more on meme coins and I and it's not any like one person's fault. It's just like the industry as a whole seem to start rewarding meme coins. I feel like we're going through this like maturing process as an industry where we have to like find what's actually important and reward the people that are actually building something useful and not the people that are, you know, going after the quick cash back. Do you think there's an argument to be made that maybe we should maybe we should be ignoring crypto headlines and focusing more on the data points just not paying all that much attention to cryptospecific headlines even things around supposedly important stuff like regulation you know what the SEC is doing developments with technological developments within the space itself >> I mostly just trade based on if it's not like if it's not broke don't fix it right the fouryear cycle has been a thing forever And at some point I it will break. But the reality is is it's probably not going to be different more often than not. And so you're better off just assuming that it's more or less the same accepting the fact that at some point in the future you will be wrong. It seems like a fool's errand trying to predict exactly when that's going to break. Because in reality, while this cycle feels different, >> we bottomed at the end of the midterm year like we always do. Yeah. And we topped in Q4 of the post having year potentially like we always do. >> As anyone will tell you, history doesn't repeat, but it does rhyme. >> Just literally do exactly what would have worked in the cycle before and you would have been incredibly successful. >> How do you see 2026 as a whole playing out and obviously with all the data that you have at your at your fingertips? >> I think there's going to be a counter trend rally probably in early 2026 is is what I think. I actually do see a scenario in the notsodistant future where altcoins potentially, I know this sounds crazy, they might actually find some lows against Bitcoin. Hello everyone and welcome to a special in-person edition of the Coin Bureau podcast. Now, if you've been in crypto for any length of time, my guest today probably doesn't need any introduction, but he is, of course, the head honcho of Into the Cryptoverse, the master of Bitcoin dominance, uh, YouTuber and crypto analyst extraordinaire, the wonderful Mr. Ben Cowan. I guess >> what's interesting if you look at at the ROI from of Bitcoin from the low for this entire cycle and you kind of ask someone in 2022 to draw out a potential path you might have just drawn exactly what happened right like diminishing returns >> the cycle length assuming the top is in October was basically within a few days the same length of the cycle the last two cycles they were all about that length as measured from the low. So in a lot of ways we got exactly what happened in prior cycles just with diminishing returns. >> Mhm. >> But in other ways it was like completely different in in in some sense and and a lot of that is again due to the altcoin market hadn't didn't really keep up with Bitcoin. And one of the main thesis for this entire bull market that I had was like okay if we're if we're if we're in a higher for in higher for longer interest rate environment and if we're in quantitative tightening it makes sense to just stick with Bitcoin. until that stuff comes to an end or we go to lower rates. If the Fed funds rate goes below the the neutral rate, which I've sort of approximated as the 2-year Treasury yield, uh when that stuff happens, it makes sense to potentially pivot because that's what happened last cycle. Like why should we be surprised that it's just happening again for like the fourth time? But in another sense, it feels very different because we topped not because of euphoria, but because of apathy, which is kind of what happened in 2019. And I think I think I've actually heard you mention this some while we've been here is that like attention is a big thing, right? And there just been a lot there's been a lack of attention to the cryptoverse. And so people were like, well, how do I sell this thing when like it doesn't really feel euphoric, but it then kind of slowly went down. I think that's where we are right now in the cycle. Let's just get out." you know, I could see a counter trend rally. Actually, in 2021, we had three red months, November, December, January, and then we had a two-month counter trend rally in February and March. And if December ends up closing red, which it very well might, that's three months in a row of red. Uh, and so I I could see, and there's also people betting on a super cycle, like there always is. And so usually there's something that happens in the early part of the midterm year that makes the super cycle guys think they're right to kind of, you know, but then it it usually leads to a lower high. So that's where I am. I I think we're going to see um some macro headwinds into about mid 2026. That actually would be it would line up perfectly with a 2019 bare market uh where you had about a 9month bare market or so. So that's kind of what I see happening. >> Yeah. I guess what's been I guess what's been confusing for a lot of people or hard or hard to understand is that against this backdrop that as you point out has so many historical parallels at the same time for the crypto industry we've had you know what objectively really positive news I mean we have a in the US a pro- crypto administration basically for the first time ever and this follows on the heels of a really anti-crypto administration I mean you know it's it's night and day the contrast between the two >> you know, we've got spot ETFs which were which was something that the industry was was kind of lusting after for a decade. If you ask me to guess the price, I would say that Bitcoin is at all-time highs or thereabouts, right? And altcoins are probably ripping hard as well. I mean, do you think that's fair to say or do do you think that's kind of is that just adjusting the is that just taking the news and trying to adjust it to fit the narrative? >> I do think narrative falls price. Absolutely. I also think the market is well ahead of what the new like where the news cycle is. You know, 6 to 12 months ahead in some cases. The market is forward-looking.
